Terminal figure - clothed Aphrodite (added by hand in pen)
West Country, c. 1640
Maker's mark IS for John Shiller [sic] of Plymouth (?)
Inscribed date 1655

fields.descriptive_line: Silver-gilt, English (possibly West Country), ca. 1640, maker's mark IS, perhaps for John Shinner (died ?1655/6)
fields.physical_description: Silver spoon with cast finial of female figure ('Aphrodite' type) and curved, fig-shaped bowl.
fields.dimensions: Length: 17.3 cm, Width: 5 cm maximum bowl width, Weight: 34.4 g

fields.public_access_description: The date and two sets of initials pricked onto the back of the bowl of this spoon suggests it commemorated a marriage. Spoons are the commonest examples of English plate to survive, and together with knives were indispensable items of tableware until supplemented by forks in the seventeenth century. They could be purchased as sets, or individually, and were owned by prosperous farmers and merchants as well as by members of the nobility. The finial on this spoon, which modern scholars have classed as an 'Aphrodite' type, is a standard figure particularly associated with the West Country (Barnstaple and, later, Plymouth). The maker's initials on the bowl are probably those of John Shinner of Plymouth, who was one of three Plymouth goldsmiths fined for substandard work by the London Wardens when they visited the city in 1633.
fields.bibliography:
Kent, Timothy. <u>West Country Silver Spoons and their Makers, 1550-1750</u>. London: J. H. Bourdon-Smith, 1992. ISBN 0952042509
Phillips Son & Neale, auctioneers, London: <u>The Alexander James collection of early English silver spoons</u>. February 9, 1979, lot 45.
Glanville, Philippa. <u>Silver in Tudor and Early Stuart England. A social history and catalogue of the national collection, 1480-1660</u>. London: Victoria and Albert Museum, 1990. ISBN 1851770305.
Snodin, Michael. <u>English Silver Spoons</u>. London: Letts, 1974. ISBN: 0850971101
Moore, Simon. <u>Cutlery for the table. A history of British table and pocket cutlery</u>. Sheffield: Hallamshire, 1999. ISBN 1874718563.
See especially  pp. 174-5.
fields.history_note:
The maker's initials on the bowl of the spoon are probably those of John Shinner of Plymouth. In 1623/4 a 'John Shinner, goldsmith' provided three new maces for the borough of Plymouth, and he was one of three Plymouth goldsmiths fined for substandard work by the London Wardens when they visited the city in 1633. He is probably the same John Shinner buried at Plymouth on 10th March 1655/6 (see Kent: 1992, p.131).

Nothing is known of the object's early provenance, though the date and initials pricked onto the back of the bowl suggests it may have commemorated a marriage. The spoon entered the collection of family plate belonging to Lord Mount Edgcumbe at an unknown date, and the Museum bought it from the family for £60 in 1956.

Historical significance: The finial on this spoon is a debased example of a type uniquely produced in the south west of England. Kent (1992, p. 17) labels finials with semi-naked female figures as 'Aphrodite'-type, and argues they echo the classically-inspired architectural styles of the sixteenth century. Spoons with the original 'Aphrodite'-style finial can nearly all be traced to Barnstaple, and are dateable to between 1590 and 1630. A spoon with a very similar finial to this example, and also marked with the maker's monogram 'I S', was sold at auction in 1979 (Phillips: 1979, lot 45). Kent (1992, p.19) described it as 'debased "Aphrodite"', and cited another comparable spoon with a Plymouth town mark to show such versions of the 'Aphrodite' form circulated beyond Barnstaple.
fields.historical_context_note: Spoons are the commonest examples of English plate to survive, and together with knives were indispensable items of tableware until supplemented by forks in the seventeenth century. They could be purchased as sets, or individually, and were owned by prosperous farmers and merchants as well as by members of the nobility. For example, in 1627 a Dorset yeoman (someone beneath the rank of gentleman who occupied and cultivated between 60 - 100 acres of land) left the not inconsiderable sum of £659 worth of household goods, including silver spoons (Glanville: 1990, p. 52). Spoons were presented as gifts at christenings and also as souvenirs at funerals. The finial, or terminal, on a spoon could be especially commissioned to represent to a personal device. The Manners family commissioned six spoons with peacock terminals (their device) from Thomas Disney in 1542 (Glanville: 1990, p.71). The finial on this spoon, however, is a standard type particularly associated with the West Country (Barnstaple and Plymouth). The size of the spoon bowl suggests it was primarily used for eating soups and stews rather than for serving.
